name: Fartlek Training
description: Swedish for 'speed play' - unstructured intervals based on feel, landmarks, or time. Mix of fast and slow running without rigid structure. Great for mental freshness.

exercises.name: Classic Fartlek (30min)
exercises.description: Traditional unstructured fartlek - pick targets and surge
exercises.instructions: 10min easy warmup. Then 20min: surge to landmarks (trees, lampposts, etc) at varying speeds, recover between. No set intervals - just play. 5min cooldown.

conditions.hamstring_moderate: Keep surges controlled, avoid maximum sprints

exercises.mentalBenefit: Breaking from structured training. Makes running playful and fun again. Great when feeling mentally stale.
exercises.paceGuidance: No rules! Some surges can be 10s, some 2min. Some fast, some moderate. Just listen to your body and play.

exercises.name: Lamp Post Fartlek
exercises.description: Structured fartlek using lamp posts as markers
exercises.instructions: 10min warmup. Then: sprint 2 lamp posts, jog 3 lamp posts. Repeat for 20min. Cooldown 5min.
exercises.paceGuidance: Sprint = 90-95% effort. Jog = very easy, full recovery. Let heart rate settle between surges.

exercises.name: 1-2-3 Minute Fartlek
exercises.instructions: 10min warmup. Then repeat 3 times: 1min hard, 1min easy, 2min hard, 2min easy, 3min hard, 3min easy (18min total). Cooldown 5min.

modifications.easier: Repeat sequence twice instead of 3 times
modifications.harder: Add a 4min surge at the end of each set

conditions.any_moderate: Monitor during 3min efforts - these are tough

exercises.paceGuidance: Hard = 85-90% effort, sustainable but challenging. Easy = very easy jog for full recovery.

exercises.name: Hill Fartlek
exercises.description: Fartlek on rolling terrain - surge the uphills, recover on flats/downs
exercises.instructions: 10min flat warmup. Then 20min: attack every uphill you encounter at hard effort, recover on flats and downhills. 5min flat cooldown.

modifications.easier: 15min on gentler hills, moderate effort on uphills

conditions.calf_moderate: Stay on gradual hills, focus on form over power
conditions.knee_moderate: Control downhills carefully, don't bomb down

exercises.terrainGuidance: Perfect for naturally hilly routes. Each hill is different, keeps it interesting. Great for trail runners.

exercises.name: Music-Based Fartlek
exercises.description: Use your playlist to structure intervals
exercises.instructions: 10min warmup. Then 20min: during upbeat/fast songs run hard, during slower songs jog easy. Let the music dictate effort. 5min cooldown.

modifications.easier: Match pace to music tempo instead of effort
modifications.harder: Sprint during choruses, recover during verses

exercises.mentalBenefit: Makes intervals feel less structured. Great if you love running with music. Can be very motivating.
exercises.paceGuidance: Hard songs = 80-90% effort. Easy songs = conversation pace. Natural variety in song lengths creates variable intervals.
exercises.playlistTip: Create a playlist alternating fast and slow songs for automatic structure.

exercises.name: Partner Fartlek
exercises.description: Run with a partner, take turns leading surges
exercises.instructions: 10min warmup together. Then 20min: partners alternate calling out surges (duration and effort). Follow leader's pace, then swap leader. 5min cooldown.

modifications.easier: Leader must call out efforts in advance ('60s surge in 3, 2, 1...')

exercises.socialBenefit: Makes running social and competitive (friendly). Great workout date or training session with friends.
exercises.paceGuidance: Leaders should match surges to their partner's fitness level. This is collaborative, not cutthroat.

exercises.name: Recovery Fartlek
exercises.description: Very easy fartlek for active recovery - just playing with pace
exercises.instructions: 25min total: mostly easy running with occasional 10-20s pickups to 'tempo' pace (not sprints). Focus on form and feeling smooth, not speed.
exercises.purpose: Teaches running economy and smooth pace changes without fatigue. Great for recovery days when you want movement variety.
exercises.paceGuidance: Base pace = very easy recovery pace. Pickups = just a bit faster, focusing on efficient form. Nothing hard.
